text.p: These are significant stories in the Nigerian press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Wives of African leaders end peace conference in Nigerian capital Abuja and plan to send peace delegations to trouble spots on the continent.
- Military ruler General Sani Abacha congratulates new British prime minister Tony Blair on his election victory and says he hopes for stronger ties between their two nations.
- The cost of a gas project being undertaken by Elf Petroleum Nigeria Ltd to feed the Nigerian liquefied gas plant has been slashed to $400 million from $500 million after revaluation.

- Participants at a workshop in Lagos suggest that as the biggest single shareholder in the African Development Bank, the continent' multilateral lending agency, Nigeria should play a more influential role in the affairs of the bank.
- Four soldiers were wounded in an early morning bomb blast in Lagos on Wednesday and four persons arrested over the incident.
- Shell oil company confirms it has reopened four oil fields which were shut two weeks ago during clashes between youths of rival tribes in the midwestern Delta state.

- Nigeria's five political parties ask electoral commision to defer state governorship elections scheduled for the last quarter of this year to 1998 so that they can hold at the same time with a presidential poll meant to restore democracy fully.
- Central Bank governor Paul Ogwuma advocates for autonomy for the bank.
- Food and beverages firms led by Nestle Foods Plc and Coca-Cola bottlers, the Nigerian Bottling Company dominate stock market activity.
